_**Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again**_ is a 2018 [jukebox
musical](/wiki/Jukebox_musical "Jukebox musical") [romantic
comedy](/wiki/Romantic_comedy "Romantic comedy") film written and directed by
[Ol Parker](/wiki/Ol_Parker "Ol Parker"), from a story by Parker, [Catherine
Johnson](/wiki/Catherine_Johnson_\(playwright\) "Catherine Johnson
\(playwright\)"), and [Richard Curtis](/wiki/Richard_Curtis "Richard Curtis").
It is a follow-up to the 2008 film _[Mamma Mia!](/wiki/Mamma_Mia!_\(film\)
"Mamma Mia! \(film\)")_ , which in turn is based on the [musical of the same
name](/wiki/Mamma_Mia! "Mamma Mia!") using the music of [ABBA](/wiki/ABBA
"ABBA"). The film features an [ensemble cast](/wiki/Ensemble_cast "Ensemble
cast"), including [Lily James](/wiki/Lily_James "Lily James"), [Amanda
Seyfried](/wiki/Amanda_Seyfried "Amanda Seyfried"), [Christine
Baranski](/wiki/Christine_Baranski "Christine Baranski"), [Julie
Walters](/wiki/Julie_Walters "Julie Walters"), [Pierce
Brosnan](/wiki/Pierce_Brosnan "Pierce Brosnan"), [Andy
García](/wiki/Andy_Garc%C3%ADa "Andy García"), [Dominic
Cooper](/wiki/Dominic_Cooper "Dominic Cooper"), [Colin
Firth](/wiki/Colin_Firth "Colin Firth"), [Stellan
Skarsgård](/wiki/Stellan_Skarsg%C3%A5rd "Stellan Skarsgård"), [Jessica Keenan
Wynn](/wiki/Jessica_Keenan_Wynn "Jessica Keenan Wynn"), [Alexa
Davies](/wiki/Alexa_Davies "Alexa Davies"), [Jeremy
Irvine](/wiki/Jeremy_Irvine "Jeremy Irvine"), [Josh Dylan](/wiki/Josh_Dylan
"Josh Dylan"), [Hugh Skinner](/wiki/Hugh_Skinner "Hugh Skinner"),
[Cher](/wiki/Cher "Cher"), and [Meryl Streep](/wiki/Meryl_Streep "Meryl
Streep"). Both a [prequel](/wiki/Prequel "Prequel") and a
[sequel](/wiki/Sequel "Sequel"), the plot is set after the events of the first
film, and also features flashbacks to 1979, telling the story of Donna
Sheridan's arrival on the island of Kalokairi and her first meetings with her
daughter Sophie's three possible fathers.

Due to the financial success of the first film, [Universal
Pictures](/wiki/Universal_Pictures "Universal Pictures") had long been
interested in a sequel. The film was officially announced in May 2017, with
Parker hired to write and direct. In June 2017, many of the original cast
confirmed their involvement, with James being cast in the role of Young Donna
that July. Filming took place from August to December 2017 in
[Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia"), and at [Shepperton
Studios](/wiki/Shepperton_Studios "Shepperton Studios") in
[Surrey](/wiki/Surrey "Surrey"), [England](/wiki/England "England"). A
[British](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") and
[American](/wiki/United_States "United States") joint venture, the film was
co-produced by [Playtone](/wiki/Playtone "Playtone"), Littlestar Productions
and [Legendary Entertainment](/wiki/Legendary_Entertainment "Legendary
Entertainment").

_Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again_ premiered at the [Hammersmith
Apollo](/wiki/Hammersmith_Apollo "Hammersmith Apollo") in
[London](/wiki/London "London") on July 16, 2018 and was released in the
United Kingdom and the United States on July 20, 2018, ten years to the week
of its predecessor's release, in both standard and [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX")
formats.[5] The film has been a box office success, grossing over $392 million
worldwide and received generally positive reviews, with critics praising the
performances and musical numbers.[6][7]

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

Sophie Sheridan is preparing for the grand reopening of her mother Donna's
hotel, following Donna's death a year earlier. She is upset because two of her
fathers, Harry and Bill, are unable to make it to the reopening and she is
having trouble in her relationship with Sky, who is in [New
York](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), over her memorializing her
mother’s life.

In 1979, a young Donna graduated from [Oxford](/wiki/Oxford "Oxford")'s [New
College](/wiki/New_College,_Oxford "New College, Oxford") with Rosie and
Tanya, and prepares to travel the world. In [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris"), she
meets and parties with Harry. They spend the night together, but Donna leaves
soon after. She later misses her boat to Kalokairi but is offered a ride by
Bill, and along the way, they are able to help a stranded fisherman, Alexio,
make it in time to stop the love of his life from marrying another.
Unbeknownst to Donna, Harry has followed her to Greece; but he arrived too
late, and sadly watches the boat sailing off in the distance.

In the present, Tanya and Rosie arrive to support Sophie with the reopening
and it’s revealed that Rosie and Bill have split up. Sophie then visits Sam,
who is still grieving over the death of Donna. Back in the past, Donna arrives
on the island and while exploring the farmhouse, a sudden storm causes her to
discover a spooked horse in the basement. She goes in search of help only to
find a young Sam riding his motorcycle and he helps her to save the horse.
Back in the present, a storm has caused serious disruption to Sophie’s plans
for the grand reopening and prevented media coverage of the event.

Back in the past, Donna and Sam are enjoying a whirlwind romance, that ends
when Donna discovers a picture of Sam’s fiancée in his drawer. A devastated
Donna demands that Sam leave the island. In the present, Sam tells Sophie
about her value to her mother. Meanwhile, Harry leaves his business deal in
[Tokyo](/wiki/Tokyo "Tokyo") to support Sophie, and separately Bill gets the
same idea. Bill and Harry meet at the docks but are told there are no boats.
However, Alexio gives Bill, Harry and the newly arrived Sky boat passage.

In the past, a depressed Donna is heartbroken over Sam but is able to channel
her anger into singing with Tanya and Rosie. She meets Bill again and they go
out on his boat; while they are gone, Sam returns, having recently ended his
engagement for Donna, but is saddened to hear that she is with another man and
leaves the island again. Donna discovers she is pregnant but has no idea which
one of her three recent lovers is the father. Sofia, the mother of the owner
of the bar where Donna and the Dynamos performed, overhears Donna’s wish to
stay on the island and offers to let Donna live at her farmhouse and Donna
happily accepts. It is there that she eventually gives birth to Sophie.

Back in the present, the guests have arrived at the party and Sophie is
reunited with her other two fathers and Sky. Sophie reveals to Sky she is
pregnant and has never felt closer to her mother, having now understood what
her mother went through. Bill and Rosie reunite over their grief for Donna.
Sophie’s estranged grandmother and Donna’s mother, Ruby, arrives despite
Sophie having decided not to invite her. She reveals that Sky tracked her down
in New York and she wants to build a real relationship with Sophie. Sophie
then performs a song with Tanya and Rosie in honor of her mother, with her
grandmother tearfully telling her afterward how proud she is of her. It is
then revealed that the manager of the hotel, Fernando, is Ruby’s ex-lover from
1959 in Mexico, and the two are joyously reunited.

Nine months later, Sophie has given birth to a baby boy named Donny. Everyone
has gathered for his christening where Tanya flirts with Fernando’s brother.
The ceremony takes place with Donna’s spirit watching over her daughter with
pride. At the end, all the characters, including Donna and the younger cast,
sing "Super Trouper" at a huge party at Hotel Bella Donna.

##
Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

  * [Amanda Seyfried](/wiki/Amanda_Seyfried "Amanda Seyfried") as Sophie Sheridan, Donna’s 25-year-old daughter, and Ruby's granddaughter.
  * [Meryl Streep](/wiki/Meryl_Streep "Meryl Streep") as Donna Sheridan-Carmichael, Sophie’s late mother, Ruby's daughter, and Sam's wife. 
    * [Lily James](/wiki/Lily_James "Lily James") as Young Donna, founder of Donna and the Dynamos.
  * [Christine Baranski](/wiki/Christine_Baranski "Christine Baranski") as Tanya Chesham-Leigh, one of Donna’s best friends and former bandmates in Donna and the Dynamos; a rich three-time divorcee. 
    * [Jessica Keenan Wynn](/wiki/Jessica_Keenan_Wynn "Jessica Keenan Wynn") as Young Tanya.
  * [Julie Walters](/wiki/Julie_Walters "Julie Walters") as Rosie Mulligan, one of Donna’s best friends and former bandmates in Donna and the Dynamos; a fun-loving author in a relationship with Bill. 
    * [Alexa Davies](/wiki/Alexa_Davies "Alexa Davies") as Young Rosie.
  * [Pierce Brosnan](/wiki/Pierce_Brosnan "Pierce Brosnan") as Sam Carmichael, an architect, Sophie's possible father, and Donna's widower. 
    * [Jeremy Irvine](/wiki/Jeremy_Irvine "Jeremy Irvine") as Young Sam.
  * [Colin Firth](/wiki/Colin_Firth "Colin Firth") as Harry Bright, Sophie's possible father, a British businessman. 
    * [Hugh Skinner](/wiki/Hugh_Skinner "Hugh Skinner") as Young Harry.
  * [Stellan Skarsgård](/wiki/Stellan_Skarsg%C3%A5rd "Stellan Skarsgård") as Bill Anderson, Sophie's possible father, a [Swedish](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") sailor and travel writer, Sofia's great-nephew, Lazaros’s cousin, and also as Kurt Anderson, Bill's obese brother. 
    * [Josh Dylan](/wiki/Josh_Dylan "Josh Dylan") as Young Bill.
  * [Dominic Cooper](/wiki/Dominic_Cooper "Dominic Cooper") as Sky, Sophie’s husband.
  * [Cher](/wiki/Cher "Cher") as Ruby Sheridan, Donna’s mother, Sophie’s grandmother, and Sam's mother-in-law.
  * [Andy García](/wiki/Andy_Garc%C3%ADa "Andy García") as Fernando Cienfuegos, the [Mexican](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") manager of the Hotel Bella Donna and an old lover of Ruby’s from 1959.
  * [Omid Djalili](/wiki/Omid_Djalili "Omid Djalili") as a Greek customs officer.
  * [Celia Imrie](/wiki/Celia_Imrie "Celia Imrie") as the Vice-Chancellor of the university at which Donna, Tanya and Rosie studied.
  * [Maria Vacratsis](/wiki/Maria_Vacratsis "Maria Vacratsis") as Sofia, a local who owns the shack that Donna stays in, which eventually becomes Donna's home, and Bill's great aunt.
  * [Panos Mouzourakis](/wiki/Panos_Mouzourakis "Panos Mouzourakis") as Lazaros, Sofia's son and Bill’s cousin who owns the bar at which both his band and Donna and the Dynamos perform.
  * [Gerard Monaco](/wiki/Gerard_Monaco "Gerard Monaco") as Alexio, a local [Greek](/wiki/Greeks "Greeks") fisherman.
  * Anna Antoniades as Apollonia, Alexio's lover and later wife.

**Cameo appearances**

  * [Björn Ulvaeus](/wiki/Bj%C3%B6rn_Ulvaeus "Björn Ulvaeus") as a university professor.
  * [Benny Andersson](/wiki/Benny_Andersson "Benny Andersson") as the pianist in the Parisian restaurant during "Waterloo".
  * [Jonathan Goldsmith](/wiki/Jonathan_Goldsmith "Jonathan Goldsmith") as Rafael Cienfuegos, Fernando Cienfuegos's widower brother.

Soundtrack](/wiki/Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again:_The_Movie_Soundtrack "Mamma

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Development")]

Due to _[Mamma Mia!](/wiki/Mamma_Mia!_\(film\) "Mamma Mia! \(film\)")_ 's
financial success, Hollywood studio chief [David Linde](/wiki/David_Linde
"David Linde"), co-chairman of [Universal Pictures](/wiki/Universal_Pictures
"Universal Pictures"), told the _[Daily Mail](/wiki/Daily_Mail "Daily Mail")_
that it would take a while, but there could be a sequel. He stated that he
would be delighted if Judy Craymer, [Catherine
Johnson](/wiki/Catherine_Johnson_\(playwright\) "Catherine Johnson
\(playwright\)"), [Phyllida Lloyd](/wiki/Phyllida_Lloyd "Phyllida Lloyd"),
[Benny Andersson](/wiki/Benny_Andersson "Benny Andersson") and [Björn
Ulvaeus](/wiki/Bj%C3%B6rn_Ulvaeus "Björn Ulvaeus") agreed to the project,
noting that there are still many ABBA songs to make use of.[10]

_Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again_ was announced on May 19, 2017, with a release
date of July 20, 2018.[11] It was written and directed by [Ol
Parker](/wiki/Ol_Parker "Ol Parker").[12] On September 27, 2017, Benny
Andersson confirmed 3 ABBA songs that would be featured in the film: "[When I
Kissed the Teacher](/wiki/When_I_Kissed_the_Teacher "When I Kissed the
Teacher")," "[I Wonder (Departure)](/wiki/I_Wonder_\(Departure\) "I Wonder
\(Departure\)")," and "[Angeleyes](/wiki/Angeleyes "Angeleyes")."[13] "I
Wonder (Departure)" was cut from the film, but is included on the soundtrack
album.

###
Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Casting")]

On June 1, 2017, it was announced that Seyfried would return as Sophie.[14]
Later that month, [Dominic Cooper](/wiki/Dominic_Cooper "Dominic Cooper")
confirmed that he would return for the sequel, along with Streep, Firth and
Brosnan as Sky, Donna, Harry, and Sam, respectively.[15] In July 2017,
Baranski was also confirmed to return as Tanya.[16] On July 12, 2017, [Lily
James](/wiki/Lily_James "Lily James") was cast to play the role of young
Donna.[17] On August 3, 2017, [Jeremy Irvine](/wiki/Jeremy_Irvine "Jeremy
Irvine") and [Alexa Davies](/wiki/Alexa_Davies "Alexa Davies") were also cast
in the film, with Irvine playing Brosnan's character Sam in a past era, and
[Hugh Skinner](/wiki/Hugh_Skinner "Hugh Skinner") to play Young Harry, Davies
as a young Rosie, played by [Julie Walters](/wiki/Julie_Walters "Julie
Walters").[18] On August 16, 2017, it was announced that [Jessica Keenan
Wynn](/wiki/Jessica_Keenan_Wynn "Jessica Keenan Wynn") had been cast as a
young Tanya, who is played by Baranski.[19] [Julie
Walters](/wiki/Julie_Walters "Julie Walters") and [Stellan
Skarsgård](/wiki/Stellan_Skarsg%C3%A5rd "Stellan Skarsgård") also reprised
their roles as Rosie and Bill, respectively.[20] On October 16, 2017, it was
announced that singer and actress [Cher](/wiki/Cher "Cher") had joined the
cast, in her first on-screen film role since 2010,[21] and her first film with
Streep since _[Silkwood](/wiki/Silkwood "Silkwood")_. The part was written
specifically for Cher, and she got to choose Andy Garcia as her romantic
partner.[22]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Filming")]

[Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography")
on the film began on August 12, 2017 in [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia"),
including the island of [Vis](/wiki/Vis_\(island\) "Vis
\(island\)").[23][24][25][26][23] In October 2017, the cast gathered at
[Shepperton Studios](/wiki/Shepperton_Studios "Shepperton Studios") in
[Surrey](/wiki/Surrey "Surrey"), [England](/wiki/England "England"), to film
song and dance numbers with Cher.[21] Filming wrapped on December 2, 2017.[27]

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Release")]

_Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again_ was released on July 20, 2018 by [Universal
Pictures](/wiki/Universal_Pictures "Universal Pictures"), in the UK, US and
other selected countries in both standard and [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX")
formats.[28][5] The film premiered on July 16, 2018 at the [Hammersmith
Apollo](/wiki/Hammersmith_Apollo "Hammersmith Apollo") in London.[29]

###
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Marketing")]

The first trailer for the film was released on December 21, 2017, in front of
_[Pitch Perfect 3](/wiki/Pitch_Perfect_3 "Pitch Perfect 3")_ , another
Universal Pictures film. Cher performed
"[Fernando](/wiki/Fernando_\(song\)#Cher_version "Fernando \(song\)")" at the
Las Vegas CinemaCon on April 25, 2018, after footage of the film was
shown.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] Universal sponsored YouTube stars the [Merrell
Twins](/wiki/Merrell_Twins "Merrell Twins") to perform a cover version of the
song "Mamma Mia" to promote the film.[30]

## Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Home media")]

_Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again_ was released via digital copy on October 9, 2018
and released on DVD, Blu-ray, and 4K UHD Combo Pack on October 23, 2018.[31]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Box office")]

As of October 11,
2018[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit),
_Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again_ has grossed $120.6 million in the United States
and Canada, and $272.2 million in other territories, for a total worldwide
gross of $392.8 million, against a production budget of $75 million.[4]

In June 2018, three weeks prior to its release, official industry tracking had
the film debuting to $27–33 million,[32] which increased to as much as $36
million by the week of its release.[33] It made $14.3 million on its first
day, including $3.4 million from Thursday night previews. It went on to debut
to $35 million, finishing second, behind fellow newcomer _[The Equalizer
2](/wiki/The_Equalizer_2 "The Equalizer 2")_ ($36 million), and besting the
opening of the first film ($27.8 million) by over 24%.[30][34] It fell 57% to
$15.1 million in its second weekend, finishing second behind newcomer
_[Mission: Impossible – Fallout](/wiki/Mission:_Impossible_%E2%80%93_Fallout
"Mission: Impossible – Fallout")_.[35][36] In its third weekend the film
grossed $9 million, dropping to fourth place, and $5.8 million in its fourth
weekend, finishing seventh.[37][38]

In the United Kingdom, the film grossed $12.7 million in its opening weekend,
topping the box office and achieving the fourth biggest opening for a film in
2018.[39] In its second weekend of international release, the film made $26.6
million (for a running total of $98.6 million). Its largest new markets were
France ($1.7 million), Poland ($1.3 million), Switzerland ($223,000) and
Croatia ($151,000), while its best holdovers were Australia ($9.5 million),
the UK ($8.6 million) and Germany ($8.2 million).[40]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mamma_Mia!_Here_We_Go_Again&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Critical response")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Lilly_James_%2835744205321%29_%28colour_edited%29.jpg/170px-
Lilly_James_%2835744205321%29_%28colour_edited%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lilly_James_\(35744205321\)_\(colour_edited\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lilly_James_\(35744205321\)_\(colour_edited\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Lily James](/wiki/Lily_James "Lily James")' performance as Young Donna was
praised by critics as a "breakout" role.[41]

On review aggregation website [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten
Tomatoes"), the film holds an approval rating of 80% based on 216 reviews, and
a weighted average of 6.3/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "_Mamma
Mia! Here We Go Again_ doubles down on just about everything fans loved about
the original—and my my, how can fans resist it?"[42] On
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic") the film has a weighted average
score of 60 out of 100 based on 46 critics, indicating "mixed or average
reviews".[43] Audiences polled by [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore
"CinemaScore") gave the film an average grade of "A–" on an A+ to F scale, the
same score as its predecessor, while [PostTrak](/wiki/PostTrak "PostTrak")
reported filmgoers gave it an 83% overall positive score.[30]

[Peter Bradshaw](/wiki/Peter_Bradshaw "Peter Bradshaw") of _[The
Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")_ termed the sequel as "weirdly
irresistible" and gave it three out of five stars. He described his reaction
to the first film as "a combination of hives and bubonic plague," but concedes
that this time, the relentlessness and greater self-aware comedy made him
smile. He concludes: "More enjoyable than I thought. But please. Enough
now."[44] [Mark Kermode](/wiki/Mark_Kermode "Mark Kermode") of _[The
Observer](/wiki/The_Observer "The Observer")_ gave the film five stars and
commented, "This slick sequel delivers sharp one-liners, joyously contrived
plot twists and an emotional punch that left our critic reeling."[45]

[Peter Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter Travers") of _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ awarded the film two and a half
stars out of five, noting the absence of Streep for the majority of the film
hindered his enjoyment, and saying, "her absence is deeply felt since the
three-time Oscar winner sang and danced her heart out as Donna Sheridan".[46]
Lindsay Bahr of _[Associated Press](/wiki/Associated_Press "Associated
Press")_ awarded the film three out of four stars, calling it "wholly
ridiculous", but complimenting its self-awareness. She also praised James'
performance and singing talent.[47] [Richard Roeper](/wiki/Richard_Roeper
"Richard Roeper") of the _[Chicago Sun-Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times "Chicago
Sun-Times")_ gave the sequel a mixed review, awarding it two stars out of
four, criticizing the reprises of "Dancing Queen" and "Super Trouper" as
uninspired, and feeling that some of the musical numbers dragged the pacing.
He considered the younger counterparts to the main characters "energetic" and
"likeable."[48] Stephanie Zacharek of _[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time
\(magazine\)")_ gave the film a mixed review, writing "_Mamma Mia! Here We Go
Again_ is atrocious. And wonderful. It's all the reasons you should never go
to the movies. And all the reasons you should race to get a ticket."[49]
